GENERAL ANESTHESIA IS NOT SLEEP! There are 4 stages through which a patient must go to effect the state of unconsciousness that is required for any surgery to happen. 1) sedation-- pt is essentially "awake", and can respond purposefully to verbal commands; 2) the excitatory phase-- prior to fully losing consciousness, the patient manifests a period of paradoxical "hyperactivity" during which s/he might experience involuntary movements that give the APPEARANCE of wakefulness-yet the patient cannot respond purposefully to verbal stimuli; 3) general anesthesia- the patient is at a level of unconsciousness such that s/he will not respond to ANY type of stimulus, particularly a painful one, such as a skin incision; 4) overdose-- this stage of anesthesia is not part of a standard (or even nonstandard) general anesthetic; it is achieved when the concentration of delivered anesthetic gases begins to induce potentially harmful effects (most often decreased blood pressure).
Be mindful that NONE of these stages of general anesthesia include rapid eye movements, or any condition which could mimic REM sleep; additionally, there is no evidence of any neurological/physiological restorative function afforded by general anesthesia. So, it bears repeating: GENERAL ANESTHESIA IS NOT NATURAL SLEEP. PATIENTS ARE NOT NAPPING. PATIENTS ARE NOT LIKELY TO EXPERIENCE DREAMS (although they may). PATIENTS ARE NOT BEING SENT ON A LOVELY VACATION. PATIENTS ARE NOT GETTING A "NICE COCKTAIL." Even this video gives only the little declarative evidence gathered to date regarding the mechanism of general anesthesia at the molecular level. There will be years and years of continuous research until the DEFINITIVE mechanism is at last discovered.
